"Help" Week For Pledges Parking Delinquents
Featured By JHU Greeks To Lose Privileges;
Projected

BY JOHN MAYO-WELLS
The trend among Hopkins fraternities is from "hell week" to
"help week", according to a recent News-Letter poll.
Eight of the twelve Interfraternity Board fraternities have active programs to help others as
part of Sheir. pledge duties. Of the
remaining four, two Plan „to institute aid programs in the near
future, and two are considering
such a policy on a long-range basis.
"Hell) week" is understood to
mean any planned period of aid,
as the term has been expanded
in meaning since Alpha Tau Omega
first instituted the idea at Indiana
University some years ago.
The "help week" projects are
usually undertaken by the pledges
Under supervision of the actives.
They include work at hospitals,
orphanages, homes for the aged,
and fund drives, such as the Heart
Fund. In most cases the fraternity
assigns definite periods of work
to the pledges
and then offers their
services to the charitable organization. In some cases, however,
the pledges volunteer their services directly.
Housework
In addition to the aid programs,
all the fraternities require
their
Pledges to work on their houses.
In some cases the "little brothers"
are assigned specific
individual
Projects, but 4p most cases they
do housecleaning and general rePair work.
Some fraternities have their
Pledges do major work, such as
exterior and interior decorating,
and one fraternity even had them
build an asphalt driveway.
Without exception, the national
Policies of the fraternities endorse
aid programs whole-heartedly, although not all advocate dropping
‘hell week" procedures completely.
As a matter of fact,
one specifically requires a "hell" period prior
to formal initiation.
In general,
however, the national policies
stress aid to the neighborhood as
a means to acquire favorable publicity and so to attract new members.
"Hell" Periods
Pive fraternities at Hopkins
Inaintain "hell" periods, ranging
from one night to one week. How"er, during these programs little if any physical punishment is
ad ministered, and only in two
eases are personally degrading and
em barrassing stunts required as
Dart of the trial period.
The most common form of hazing involves "rides." Actives take
their pledges to out-of-the-way
torners of both city and country
and leave them there to get back

Nine JHU Fraternities
Solicit For Heart Fund
Nine Hopkins fraternities
participated in the annual
Heart Association drive on Sunday, February 14, Dick Cohn,
President of the IFB, announced
this week.
Sixty-five boys solicited funds
In the city of Baltimore. Cohn
said,"The participation by Hopkins fraternity men in this drive
Is a part of the IFB's program
of participataion in community
benefitting services." He added,
"The IFB is now planning to
expand this program and is
working on such things as volunteer work in hospitals and
like institutions."

The Parking Problem
Complaints have come from the DSRC that dorm students'
cars parked on the side lanes of Charles Street have been damaged
by other traffic in the lanes. The dorm boys therefore began
parking on the lawn in front of the dorm. During the present
construction period, nothing more could be done to destroy the
beauty of that lawn that hasn't already been done by the
contractors in building the new ,dorm. But this solution to the
parking problem, dorm phase, is obviously not a good one.
Next year, if the Plant Manager's office gets the 90% occupancy
it hopes for the anew dorm, the problem will be about twice
as bad.
The University has been working with its architects to
nd a way of providing parking space on campus. The first
announcement of this work was made in late October. The time
is rapidly approaching when the University will have to solve
the problem or admit that there will be no facilities for campus
students next year.

Another Farce?
Last year at Christmas time the editors of the News-Letter
stowed a fifth of Christmas spirits in the bottom drawer of a filing
cabinet and then left it there for two hours. Upon their return
they discovered that the whiskey was gone, although it was impossible that anyone outside of those who placed it in the cabinet
could have known that it was there for the two specified hours.
Last week members of the editorial board of the Hullabaloo,
ignoring the News-Letter loss, placed in the back of a desk drawer,
deposits that grew to 074.25 over a period of about three weeks.
As in the case of the News-Letter whiskey theft, soine light-fingered
person took it. As far as Levering basement is concerned, it has
been a proven Thet that the Honor Code is not carried out of the
class room. News-Letter staffs of other years have passed the word
down to this staff that the smallest amount of money concealed in
an inconspicuous place is not safe for even a couple of hours.
Despite this warning, the editors and business staff of the
Hullabaloo felt that over a hundred dollars would be safe in their
office. This is a case of gross negligence and carelessness on their
part. The money could have just as easily been deposited in the
bank by any one of the members of the staff, and, since the yearbook has very few cash transactins, it needs little cash on hand.
The staff of a publication that has a history of The Hullabaloo,
that arrives at its subscribers' homes in late August, should be
alert to what seems an inherent nonchalance in its work. This
year's staff got the book off to its best start in the past five years,
but it is now in danger of stumbling into the same pitfalls that
last year's annual did. We certainly hope that business manager
Herb Alterman 's beginning-of-the-year statement, "There will
be no repetition of last year's farce," is true, but we seriously
doubt it.

of conversation.
The blame does not fall on any
particular group; librarians, undergraduates and graduates alike,

The librarians, although very
capable, often carry on loud conversations when helping students.
This, and the fact that they do
little to stop students who are disrupting the quiet that should prevail in the library, seems to incite
frequenters of the library to carry
on at a greater pace than before.
It incites them to greater levels
of noise.

or three's, discussing their latest

were able to purge in the last
exam. There should be, on the
part of these graduate students, a
certain amount of consideration
shown for those students who are
conscientious enough concerning
their careers at college to make
use of the library and the facilities
It offers.

"Help" Week For Pledges Parking Delinquents
Featured By JHU Greeks To Lose Privileges;
Projected

BY JOHN MAYO-WELLS
The trend among Hopkins fraternities is from "hell week" to
"help week", according to a recent News-Letter poll.
Eight of the twelve Interfraternity Board fraternities have active programs to help others as
part of Sheir. pledge duties. Of the
remaining four, two Plan „to institute aid programs in the near
future, and two are considering
such a policy on a long-range basis.
"Hell) week" is understood to
mean any planned period of aid,
as the term has been expanded
in meaning since Alpha Tau Omega
first instituted the idea at Indiana
University some years ago.
The "help week" projects are
usually undertaken by the pledges
Under supervision of the actives.
They include work at hospitals,
orphanages, homes for the aged,
and fund drives, such as the Heart
Fund. In most cases the fraternity
assigns definite periods of work
to the pledges
and then offers their
services to the charitable organization. In some cases, however,
the pledges volunteer their services directly.
Housework
In addition to the aid programs,
all the fraternities require
their
Pledges to work on their houses.
In some cases the "little brothers"
are assigned specific
individual
Projects, but 4p most cases they
do housecleaning and general rePair work.
Some fraternities have their
Pledges do major work, such as
exterior and interior decorating,
and one fraternity even had them
build an asphalt driveway.
Without exception, the national
Policies of the fraternities endorse
aid programs whole-heartedly, although not all advocate dropping
‘hell week" procedures completely.
As a matter of fact,
one specifically requires a "hell" period prior
to formal initiation.
In general,
however, the national policies
stress aid to the neighborhood as
a means to acquire favorable publicity and so to attract new members.
"Hell" Periods
Pive fraternities at Hopkins
Inaintain "hell" periods, ranging
from one night to one week. How"er, during these programs little if any physical punishment is
ad ministered, and only in two
eases are personally degrading and
em barrassing stunts required as
Dart of the trial period.
The most common form of hazing involves "rides." Actives take
their pledges to out-of-the-way
torners of both city and country
and leave them there to get back

Nine Hopkins fraternities
participated in the annual
Heart Association drive on Sunday, February 14, Dick Cohn,
President of the IFB, announced
this week.
Sixty-five boys solicited funds
In the city of Baltimore. Cohn
said,"The participation by Hopkins fraternity men in this drive
Is a part of the IFB's program
of participataion in community
benefitting services." He added,
"The IFB is now planning to
expand this program and is
working on such things as volunteer work in hospitals and
like institutions."

The Parking Problem
Complaints have come from the DSRC that dorm students'
cars parked on the side lanes of Charles Street have been damaged
by other traffic in the lanes. The dorm boys therefore began
parking on the lawn in front of the dorm. During the present
construction period, nothing more could be done to destroy the
beauty of that lawn that hasn't already been done by the
contractors in building the new ,dorm. But this solution to the
parking problem, dorm phase, is obviously not a good one.
Next year, if the Plant Manager's office gets the 90% occupancy
it hopes for the anew dorm, the problem will be about twice
as bad.
The University has been working with its architects to
nd a way of providing parking space on campus. The first
announcement of this work was made in late October. The time
is rapidly approaching when the University will have to solve
the problem or admit that there will be no facilities for campus
students next year.

Another Farce?
Last year at Christmas time the editors of the News-Letter
stowed a fifth of Christmas spirits in the bottom drawer of a filing
cabinet and then left it there for two hours. Upon their return
they discovered that the whiskey was gone, although it was impossible that anyone outside of those who placed it in the cabinet
could have known that it was there for the two specified hours.
Last week members of the editorial board of the Hullabaloo,
ignoring the News-Letter loss, placed in the back of a desk drawer,
deposits that grew to 074.25 over a period of about three weeks.
As in the case of the News-Letter whiskey theft, soine light-fingered
person took it. As far as Levering basement is concerned, it has
been a proven Thet that the Honor Code is not carried out of the
class room. News-Letter staffs of other years have passed the word
down to this staff that the smallest amount of money concealed in
an inconspicuous place is not safe for even a couple of hours.
Despite this warning, the editors and business staff of the
Hullabaloo felt that over a hundred dollars would be safe in their
office. This is a case of gross negligence and carelessness on their
part. The money could have just as easily been deposited in the
bank by any one of the members of the staff, and, since the yearbook has very few cash transactins, it needs little cash on hand.
The staff of a publication that has a history of The Hullabaloo,
that arrives at its subscribers' homes in late August, should be
alert to what seems an inherent nonchalance in its work. This
year's staff got the book off to its best start in the past five years,
but it is now in danger of stumbling into the same pitfalls that
last year's annual did. We certainly hope that business manager
Herb Alterman 's beginning-of-the-year statement, "There will
be no repetition of last year's farce," is true, but we seriously
doubt it.

The blame does not fall on any

The librarians, although very

This, and the fact that they do

on at a greater pace than before.
It incites them to greater levels
of noise.

were able to purge in the last
exam. There should be, on the
part of these graduate students, a
certain amount of consideration
shown for those students who are
conscientious enough concerning
their careers at college to make
use of the library and the facilities
It offers.
